ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was:
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I think this is a very important and relevant class, keeping up with the high standards kept by Yale in general, and F&ES in particular. The topics covered and the readings were all excellent. The instructor was really good. Earlier, my ideas of tropical forest ecology was based on the previous classes I have taken on this topic. This class made me realize the serious drawbacks of the earlier classes, and also in my knowledge. Its apt coverage of the topic and the depth helped with understanding various streams of thought in the matter and study the topic deeply at a graduate-student level. I developed a clearer understanding of the theoretical background regarding many tropical-forest phenomena, including biodiversity, community assembly, etc., which would have been far more difficult without this class. The class helped me a lot to organize my thoughts in line with my research.
I learned a lot about plant and forest ecology, and about current research on forest conservation.
good survey course on tropical forest ecology.
So many new concepts on competition and interaction between species in tropical forests; in-depth looks into the human-forest interface

I learned a ton about tropical ecology! My knowledge of tropical ecology was limited coming into the class and after taking the class I feel much more prepared to immerse myself deeper into the field of tropical ecology.
I really got a lot out of the articles we read and the discussions in small groups. I also appreciated the focus on theory since it was a gap in my knowledge before taking the course.
Strong foundation in tropical systems.
Understanding of basic concepts, and current scholarship around tropical ecology and forestry
It was great for thinking about the ecological complexity of tropical forests.
My knowledge of tropical forest ecosystems (threats, processes, species) has been greatly increased, as well as my desire to learn more and work in those ecosystems.

I learned the fundamentals of Ecology of tropical forests, and the complex web of interactions that are at play. Although some concepts were known to me, I was able to strengthen my scientific understanding of some methods of sampling and the implications of some cutting-edge research for policy decisions

narratives.question_text: How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations?
comments: I would say I got more than I expected. I was expecting the course to be of a refresher class, to brush up my knowledge. Rather it opened up a whole new, critical set of knowledge regarding a more comprehensive perspective on tropical forest ecology than I had before. It helped me a lot with streamlining my thoughts, give me new insights, and gave with with much-needed conceptual clarity. Now I feel very confident to talk about the topic.
A lot of the ecology as basic, could have used some more hard skills and less writing.
It exceeded my expectations

The knowledge, skills, and insights I gained from this class surpassed my expectations. I was slightly worried at the beginning of the class that the material would be too elementary for me but I was wrong to worry. Every class tackled a new important topic in tropical ecology in a way that was easy to understand and relevant to modern issues that need to be addressed in tropical ecology.
Perfectly. I loved this course and got everything and more than I expected.
There was a good match
I think I expected a bit more in-depth or technical knowledge
My expectations were fairly in-line with reality; the course covered many topics and spent a good amount of time on each one.

I knew that this course didn't explicitly involved the human dimension. However, I was very happy to know that Liza was very open to the fact that students could choose their research topic out of a bunch of different topics, involving human-nature relations in tropical forest landscapes

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strength: Its organized nature, conceptual clarity, up-to-date readings; friendly and knowledgeable instructor; Weakness: Conservation aspect of the class could have a stronger interdisciplinary basis.
I really enjoyed the class, but I think there could have been less textbook material/lecture, and more journal articles/discussion. It would also be nice to not run over time every day.
Lots of great literature but I think some of it was redundant. I would have loved to learn more about project design.
I love how homework questions are discussed in class in small groups, it made me understand the concepts much better

Strengths: -Examples were relevant to modern contemporary tropical forest issues. -Course was very well structured -Assignments were an appropriate level. They challenged me and also inspired me. Weaknesses: -N/A I loved this class!
Liza is a great lecturer. The readings were also really interesting and always at an appropriate level.

Strengths - great introduction. Weaknesses - if you've taken silviculture, some of the content in this class will be repetitive. Would be great to have a "silvics" basics lecture for a couple sessions to get 1st years up to speed.

Strength: applies to people are varying experience levels. I don't have a super in depth ecology background, but the material was still accessible. Good energy in the room. Active discussion and debate. No weaknesses off hand.

I really liked the themes selected and papers used to illustrate them. I also really appreciated the short writing assignments for every reading--it helped keep me on task and made sure I got them done every week. The study guide Liza gave us before the midterm was also excellent and very helpful--she clearly had a lesson plan laid out in terms of what we were expected to learn and she was great at communicated it to us. It would have been nice to go a bit more in depth at times. Some of the small group discussions didn't really do justice to the complexity treated in the papers we read

The course material is very engaging by itself. I can't think of anything that would specifically have improved the class, besides maybe a little bit more feedback on weekly assignments for understanding.

I would say that the course has everything that is essential for an entry-level practitioner interested in working in the tropics. The way in which all activities are planned really helped me understand the problems, its implications and possible solutions

narratives.question_text: What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class?
comments: Take this class if you need (a) a conceptual foundation in tropical forest ecology as a science; (b) you look forward to do ecological or sociological research in tropical forests; or (c) if you need a science course where learning is fun and the instructor is brilliant and resourceful.
If you have any interest in tropical forests, this is a great class.
Material starts of somewhere between basic and intermediate so give it a try even though you don't know much about the tropics.
Read the textbook!
Liza is a great instructor. She is open to ideas, funny and clearly a great researcher. S
If you have a little bit of background in ecology or forestry and want to break into tropical forests as an area of interest, this course is for you.
Although this course does not offer a field trip to Panama, is completely worth the time and the study hours!
